original_title: Transistor Radio Repair, More Complex Than It Seems
original_content:
The humble transistor radio is one of those consumer devices that stubbornly refuses to go away, but its fair to say that its not the mover and shaker in the world of electronics it might once have been. Thus its also not a staple of the repair bench anymore, where fixing a pocket radio might have been all in a days work decades ago now theyre a rare sight. [David Tipton] has a Philips radio from were guessing the later half of the 1960s which didnt work, and were along for the ride as he takes us through its repair.
Its an extremely conventional design of the era, with a self-oscillating mixer, 455 kHz IF amplifier, and class AB audio amplifier. The devices are a little archaic by todays standards, with comically low-gain germanium transistors and passives from the Ark. Injecting a signal reveals that the various stages all work, but that mixer isnt oscillating. A lot of fault-finding ensues, and perhaps with a little bit of embarrassment, he eventually discovers a blob of solder shorting a collector resistor to ground. All isnt over though, for the volume pot is also kaput. Who knew that the track from a modern component could be transplanted into one from the 1960s?
title: 1960年代のフィリップスラジオの修理に成功！
body: 記事では、1960年代後半のフィリップスのラジオの修理の過程が紹介されています。ラジオは古いデザインで、各部分が正常に機能していなかったため、原因を見つけるために様々なトラブルシューティングが行われました。修理の結果、短絡していたはんだのために一部のパーツが壊れたが、最終的には修復に成功しました。
